editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: ACT For a LEAVIE Of Horse and Foot Within this KINGDOM, FOR THEIR NECESSARY Defence.
EDINBVRGH, Printed by Evan Tyler, Printer to the Kings most Excellent Majesty, 1650.

div.head: Edinburgh, 25 June, 1650.
div.p:
THe Estates of Parliament having considered the dangerousposture of affaires in this Kingdome, both in respect of intestine and forraigne enemies, And although it hes pleased God, to breake the power of malignants in this Kingdome, Yet knowing that they will be uncessant in their designes and attempts in laying hold of all opportunities to involve this Kingdome in new troubles, And withall, having received severall intelligences of imminent dangers to the cause and this Nation from abroad by approaching of an armie of Sectaries towards this Kingdom. And being obliged in discharge of the trust Committed to them to take care of the safetie of the Nation, As they resolve for themselves to use all lawfull means and peaceble wayes to prevent the dangers, so they have thought fit to give warning to the severall shires and burghs, That according to the law of God, nature and nations, and according to the duties which they by so many sacred bonds owe to the Covenant and cause, to the King and Kingdom, they might be in a condition and posture for defending all those and whatsoever is neer and dear to them against all invasion. Likeas for the stopping of the mouth of Calumnie removing all scrouples and mistakes, and clearing to the consciences of all the lawfulnesse, necessitie and justice of
their resolutions & proceedings, & that they may have the greater assurance of Gods blessing and presence to all their indevores, The Estates of Parliament declare and assure that they injoyne the following levy of horse and foot for this end allanerlie of meer, just and necessary defence of this Kingdom from invasion, without any designe or intention of invading, any who shal not first invade this Kingdome; And therefore the saids Estates of Parliament doe hereby ordain the whole shyres and burghes within this Kingdome presently to raise and have inreadinesse the whole number of horse, men, and armes, and the foot appointed to be levied by the act of Parliament of the 6 day of August. 1649. Together with what was not put forth of the third part of the horse & fourt part of the foot, conform to the act of levie of the 28. day of Febr. 1649. And siclike the hail Burrows of this Kingdom to raise & have in readines the proportion of horse according to the said act of the 28, of February 1649. So far as alreadie is not put forth by them, Or in their option three Foot for every horse & man, & then according to the Act 6. of August. 1649. For the present levie; all which are set down in the list hereunto subjoyned. And ordaines the forces foresaid To be brought to Randevoweses against such dayes as are designed by the Parliament by a particular Act of the date of thir presents herewith sent, and that at such a convenient place within the Shire as the Committee of war, with advise of the officers shal think fit, And appoints them at that time and place to be inrolled and listed under their respective officers, And either to march if they shal receive orders, or to returne to remain with their out-putters incase they receive not orders from the Parliament or their
Committee; Providing alwayes, that it is not hereby to be understood that the Committee of Estates shall have any power to give orders to the said forces for bringing them forth of the shires for any other ends then for the just and necessarie defence of this Kingdome from invasion as is exprest in the narrative of this Act. And the saids Estates of Parliament ordains everie troup to consist of 75. Troupers, and every regiment of horse to be made up of 6. troupes at least, and 8. Troups at most, sicklike every companie of foot to consist of 126 souldiers, and every regiment of foot to be made up of 8. companies, And likewise they ordaine the present standing troupes be recruited and made up to the number of 75. in every troup out of the number of horses to be now levyed forth of the severall shyres respective, and these recruites not to be brought forth of the shires til there be a necessitie of bringing forth the new levy foresaid, according to this present Act, And sicklike that these recrutes be dismissed with the new Leavie, when the same shall be dismissed; And farther, the saids Estates of Parliament declare they will nominate and appoint the officers of regiments, troups and companies from a Colonell to a Captain inclusive without prejudice to the Committes of shires in time coming anent any power whatsomever granted to them for nomination of their own rootmasters conforme to any preceding acts of levie, and do give power and war â€¢ and to the Committees of War of the severall shyres with advise of the Collonels respective, according to their severall divisions if they be present to nominat and appoint the officers inferior to a Captain, and to the Magistrates and Counsels of Burghes to
make choyse of their officers under the degree of a Captain according to the proportions to be put forth by them, Providing alwayes they make choise of such as are fit for the service, and are qualified as is exprest in the 26. Act seventeenth of February, 1649. which ordains that such as are malignant and disaffected to the present work of reformation, and Covenants, and against whom there is just cause of Exception or just ground of jealousie because of their disaffection, or any person given to Drunkennes, Swearing, Uncleanes, or any other Scandalous offence, Be not made choyse of, but onlyable men, and such who are of known affection unto, & approved fidelitie and integritie in the cause of God, & of a blameles and Christian Conversation. And ordaines the saids Committees of Warr and Counsells of Burghes, after they have made choyse of their under officers, to return a roll of their names to the Committee appointted for purging the armie, before the day of their randezvows. And gives power to the Committees of War and Counsells of Burghs within their severall Jurisdictions respective, To devide and lay on proportionally the horse according to the maintenance upon the severall heritors and others lyable in putting forth the same; And It is declared That the greatest rent of these to be joyned for making up one horse shall provide the horse, And the rest that joyne, to contribute according to one hundereth and threescore pounds for ilk horse and man, With power also to the Committees of Warr of the severall Shires respective, to set prices upon horses fit for the service, And to take them as they shall find necessarie for the good of the same, And Sicklyke appoints the heritors and others lyable in putting forth horse and
Foot to bring them to the Randezvous well mounted and armed under the paine of 200. merks for ilk horse & man, and 100. Merks for ilk Footman. To be payed by the heritors & others failing to bring sufficient horse, men and armes respective to the randezvows as said is, To be exacted by the select persons nominate in the severall Shyres for viewing of the horse and armes; And this penaltie to be exacted by and attour the putting forth of the horse, men and armes as is afforesaid; And incase of their return from the Randezvous, appoints the Committees of War of the severall Shyrs to take the particular heritors and others lyable in putting forth Horse and Foot obliged for having them in reddinesse within 24. houres after advertisment from the Parliament or Committee of Estates, under the pain aforesaid, Andappoints the counsels of Burghs to take the out-putters within brughs, obliged in the likemanner under the same paine. And further the saids Estates upon consideration of the great abuses in former levies committed by officers in taking of mony from the heritors & others aforesaid who are lyable in putting forth of horse-men and foot in place of their said men, Declare That whatsoever officer shall be found to have done so, shall not only be cashiered from his charge, but also branded with ane mark of infamie and disgrace, and shal be obliged to repay the quadruple, & to be imprisoned ay and while he pay the same, Excepting such officers who are to Levie their horsemen in the Shyres beyond Spey, who are hereby permitted to take 200. pounds for every horse and man, or the man well mounted in the option of the outputter; Providing The said Officers make up their number of good sufficient able horse and men at the
day of Randezvows appointed for the said Shyres beyond Spey, as said is. And the saids Estates of Parliament doe give power to the saids Committees of War in the several shyres of this Kingdome with advice of the Colonells To doe all things conform to the former acts of Levies as they shall find necessary for the more speedy and effectuall raising and having in readines at the Randezvous, the Horse and foot abovewritten, And appoints the saids Committees, after the receipt of this act, to sit continually & every day till they execute the same, And return immediatly an accompt of their deligence to the Parliament or Committee of Estates, With power to them to fine those of their number who shall be absent in 20. Merks Scots for every dayes absence.
